FtaRooDetails.FtaFullName: AGREEMENT FREE TRADE BETWEEN THE GOVERNMENT OF THE HASHEMITE KINGDOM OF JORDAN AND THE GOVERNMENT OF THE ARAB REPUBLIC OF Egypt
FtaRooDetails.AdminProc:
Now you will need to complete a certificate of origin (CoO) in order to demonstrate that your product indeed qualifies under the rules of origin.
It will have to be presented at the customs of the destination country during the clearance procedure, when the customs officer asks whether your product qualifies under Egypt-Jordan
FtaRooDetails.AdminProcCooAuth: The certification type under Egypt-Jordan is by authorized body. This means that certificate of origin is issued by an agency empowered for this purpose.
FtaRooDetails.AdminProcCooNoAuth: The certification type under Egypt-Jordan is self-certification. This means that certificate of origin can be issued by the exporter himself.
FtaRooDetails.AdminProcDownload: 1. Download and complete the certificate of origin (CoO) for Egypt-Jordan agreement.
FtaRooDetails.RooSelfAssessmentDesc:
In order to qualify for preferential treatment, your product will need to satisfy the rules of origin under the agreement.
Complete this short self-assessment to find out whether your product may qualify in relation to this tariff line.
FtaRooDetails.AddlMrktInfoDesc:
In the following are deep links to additional information available in other ITC tools.
If you have any questions about that please contact us at marketanalysis@intracen.org.

RooData.RooText: Pursuant to the provisions set out in Article No. (II) (Paragraph B) concerning determination of the origin of merchandise manufactured in either Party, and which contain materials originating from a third party, the criterion associated with share of domestic value-added shall be considered to determine the rules of origin for such merchandise, provided that such shall be no less than forty percent (40%). The share of value-added shall be calculated as follows: Share of Domestic Value-Added = [(Ex-Factory Value of Final Product - Value of Imported Materials Involved in the Manufacture)/Final Ex-Factory Value of Merchandise] x 100% The criterion associated with the share of value added shall hereby constitute the basis for such calculation, pursuant to provisions of the present Protocol, while taking into consideration one of the two following criteria: A. The change to customs-based classification, with clear identification of the headings and sub-headings as a part of the Harmonised System (H.S. Code) up to six digits; B. The manufacture processes, with clear identification of the specific process that determines the origin of the concerned good/ commodity.

RooProvision.ProvisionGlossary: A provision which allows to consider goods obtained in as well as processing taking place in one FTA member country as originating in another.
RooProvision.ProvisionLegalExtract:
Article 3 : BILATERAL CUMULATION OF ORIGIN
Notwithstanding the provisions contained in Article No. (II) hereabove, and in pursuance of
the requirements of the present Protocol, products of Jordanian origin shall hereby be
deemed to be originating in Egypt. This shall not be conditional on whether such products
have been subjected to sufficient industrial transformation or manufacture, but provided
that such have been the subject of industrial transformation or manufacture beyond the
operations referred to in Article No. (VI) of the present Protocol.
Notwithstanding the provisions contained in Article No. (II) hereabove, and in pursuance of
the requirements of the present Protocol, products of Egyptian origin shall hereby be
deemed to be originating in Jordan. This shall not be conditional on whether such products
have been subjected to sufficient industrial transformation or manufacture, but provided
that such have been the subject of industrial transformation or manufacture beyond the
operations referred to in Article No. (VI) of the present Protocol.

RooProvision.ProvisionGlossary: A provision that allows a small amount of non-originating materials to be used in the production of the good without affecting its originating status. The provision acts as the relaxation of the rules of origin.

A provision stipulating that once a part or intermediate material obtains originating status under an FTA, it is considered to be 100% originating when used for further processing even if inputs used for the production of this part or intermediate material were not originating.

A provision that relates to reclaims or refunds of customs duties previously paid on inputs. In the context of FTAs, duty drawback provision, usually relates to the ability to claim back duties paid on non-originating materials used to produce the final good which is exported under preferential tariffs.

A provision that allows a good to be temporarily removed from the FTA territory and processed in the third party country without affecting origin determination of the final product. No account is taken of the fact that the good has left the territory of an FTA during the production process.
A provision that clarifies the origin determination process of accessories, spare parts or tools delivered with the good.
A provision listing products considered obtained entirely in the territory of one (or more, depending on the agreement) FTA party without the addition of any non-originating materials.
RooProvision.ProvisionLegalExtract:
Article 4 : ENTIRELY ACQUIRED PRODUCTS
The following products shall be deemed to be entirely acquired in Egypt or Jordan:
A. Mining products derived or extracted from the territory, seabed or sea ocean of either country;
B. Vegetal products yielded or harvested in either country;
C. Live animals bred and raised in either country;
D. Products acquired from live animals raised in either country;
E. Products acquired from the business of hunting or fishing performed in either country;
F. Products acquired from maritime fishing and other products taken from the sea by a
vessel of either country;
G. Products mentioned in Paragraph No. (F) hereinabove, which are processed in the
processing vessels (factory ships) of either country;
H. Used articles that are only suitable for recapture of source materials;
I. Waste products generated from industrial processes performed in either country;
J. Products extracted from the territory or the subterranean water resources thereof
which are located outside the territorial waters of either country, as long as such
practices are undertaken for the purpose of rightful exploitation, whether above or
under the ground; and,
K. Goods manufactured or processed specifically from products referred to in Items Nos. (A) to (J).

RooProvision.ProvisionGlossary: A provision that lists operations which do not confer origin. They are considered below the threshold of sufficient production / processing.
RooProvision.ProvisionLegalExtract:
Article 6 : INSUFFICIENT MANUFACTURE OR TRANSFORMATION
The following operations of manufacture or transformation shall be deemed to be
insufficient for the purpose of conferring the status of origin, independent of any change in tariff heading:
A. Operations necessary for preservation of materials in their normal state during
transportation or storage (ventilation; diffusion; drying; refrigeration and cooling;
preservation in water that is saline, sulphate, or mixed with other substances;
removal of rotten parts; and the like).
B. Simple operations (such as cleaning; sifting; sorting; washing; classifying; labelling;
organising, including grouping merchandise into groups; painting (varnishing); segmenting, etc.).
C. Operations associated with repackaging; and consolidation and splitting of packages.
D. Simple operations associated with packing merchandise into bottles, flaxes, bags,
and boxes; of installing labels on vials and bottles; and similar simple processes of packaging.
E. Operations associated with labelling merchandise or packaging materials thereof, as
well as other similar processes of tagging.
F. Operations associated with mixing simple substances, even if they are of different
species, and therefore do not meet the conditions laid out in the present protocol
regarding the acquisition of the status of origin of either Jordan or Egypt.
G. Simple operations associated with assembling, and which are intended to produce finished products.
H. Cumulation of two or more of the operations referred to hereinabove under Items No. (A) to (G).
I. Slaughter of animals.

RooProvision.ProvisionGlossary: A provision that provides how to calculate regional value content in the shipped good.

A provision which specifies that the origin of certain materials (referred to as indirect or neutral) used in the production process should not be taken into account when determining the origin of the final good.
RooProvision.ProvisionLegalExtract:
Article 8 : COMPONENTS OF NEUTRALITY
In order to establish the Egyptian or Jordanian origin of products, it shall not be necessary to
specify origin of electric power, fuel, facilities and equipment, machinery and instruments
used to acquire the respective product.

RooProvision.ProvisionGlossary: A provision requiring goods that are claiming preferential treatment under an FTA to be shipped directly from the FTA country of origin to the FTA country of destination.
RooProvision.ProvisionLegalExtract:
Article 9 : DIRECT TRANSPORT
The exemption scheme provided for under the Agreement shall hereby solely apply to such
products and materials transported between Jordan and Egypt, without a transit route
through the territory of a third country.
Nevertheless, materials originating in Jordan or Egypt, which constitute a part of the same
consignment, may maintain the origin thereof, even though such shall be moved or
transported through the territory of other countries, and may be granted possible
arrangements of transport or interim storage, provided that such materials shall remain
under the surveillance and control of the customs authority of the country of transit, and
shall not be subjected to any other operations, with the exception of landing or trans-
shipment or any other operation intended for the maintenance thereof.
The process of indirect transport or transit of such products shall be acknowledged and
declared to the customs authority of the country of import, on the basis of:
? The waybill and transport documents performed at the country of export; and,
? The certificate issued by the customs authorities at the country of transit, containing
an exact description of the respective merchandise, the date of landing and trans-
shipment thereof, and the circumstances experienced by such products during the
passage or transit thereof.
In the absence of the above documentation, any other document issued and authorised by
the customs authorities of the country of import shall hereby be sufficient.

RooProvision.ProvisionGlossary: A provision stating that for the purpose of determining the origin of goods, all working and processing needs to be carried out within the territory of parties to the agreement without interruption.
A provision that clarifies whether packaging should be accounted for when determining the origin of the product.

A provision determining how non-originating and originating fungible materials should be tracked (accounted for) when both types are stored together and/or used to produce originating and non-originating goods. It allows both types of goods to be tracked not through physical identification and separation but based on an accounting or inventory management system.
A provision that clarifies circumstances under which sets can be considered originating. In particular, it refers to situations where not all of the items in the set are originating.
RooProvision.ProvisionLegalExtract:
Article 7 : SETS AND MIXTURES
Pursuant to Rule No. (3) of the General Rules for the Interpretation of the Harmonized
System, sets consisting of originating and non-originating materials shall hereby be
considered to be originating sets, provided that the originating materials involved in the
composition or make-up thereof shall account for no more than fifteen percent (15%) of the
ex-factory price of the respective set.

RooProvision.ProvisionGlossary: A provision which allows an originating good to be purchased in a third party (non-FTA) country during an exhibition and imported into an FTA country under preferential treatment.

CooProvision.ProvisionGlossary: A provision that details the type of origin documentation that needs to be provided to claim preferential tariffs under an FTA.
CooProvision.ProvisionLegalExtract:
Article 10 : ESTABLISHMENT OF ORIGIN
The products originating in Jordan or in Egypt, pursuant to the present Protocol, and traded
between the two respective countries, shall hereby be accompanied by a national certificate
or origin according to the (annexed) template, along with the fulfilment of all data requirements.
Article 11 : PROCEDURES FOR ISSUANCE AND VALIDATION OF CERTIFICATES OF ORIGIN
1. Certificates of origin in respect of merchandise originating in Jordan shall hereby be
issued by the Chambers of Commerce and Industry and shall be verified and
validated by the Jordanian Ministry of Industry and Trade.
2. Certificates of origin in respect of merchandise originating in Egypt shall hereby be
issued, verified and validated by the General Organisation for Import and Export Control.
3. The competent authorities of the country of export shall hereby be responsible to
issue and release certificates of origin upon written request submitted by individual
exporters or by their authorised representative or designee and under the sole
responsibility thereof.
4 Individual exporters or their authorised representative or designee shall hereby
provide information and complete all the required fields within the template of the
certificates in a legible manner. All data requirements shall be fulfilled and products
shall be described in the spaces intended for that purpose, without leaving empty or
blank spaces. If the spaces allotted for this purpose are not entirely filled out, a
horizontal line is drawn underneath the last line of writing.
5 Individual exporters requesting issuance of a certificate of origin shall be required to
submit the documentation necessary to fulfil the remaining requirements set forth
in the Protocol upon request by the competent authorities concerned with the
issuance of certificates of origin.
6 Certificates of origin shall be issued by authorities concerned with issuance of
certificates of origin in the event that the exported products or merchandise have
been already conferred the status of origin and have fulfilled all the remaining
requirements set out in the present Protocol.
7 The date of issuance of the certificate of origin shall be written up in field intended
for this purpose therein.
8 The certificates of origin shall be issued and released by competent authorities at
export, in execution or in validation of the process of export.
Article 13 : PROCEDURES FOR ISSUANCE OF SUBSTITUTE CERTIFICATE OF ORIGIN
1 In case of theft, loss or damage of a certificate of origin, the concerned exporter may
apply to the competent authorities that issued the initial certificate to request the
issuance of a substitute copy on the basis of the documents of export in the possession thereof.
2 Endorsement of a substitute certificate of origin shall be made in Arabic and shall
indicate the following, ‘Certified True Copy of Initial Certificate'. The substitute
certificate shall bear the same date of issuance of the initial certificate of origin. This
shall be taken into consideration when calculating the terms of validity and time
limits of the respective certificate of origin.
Article 15 : SUBMISSION OF CERTIFICATES OF ORIGIN
Certificates of origin shall be submitted to the competent authorities of the country of
import in conformity with the procedures in place in each country and shall be drawn up in
Arabic, pursuant to the template applicable within the League of Arab States (LAS).

CooProvision.ProvisionGlossary: A provision which lists exemptions from the requirement to provide a proof of origin. Under certain circumstances originating goods can be imported into an FTA country without a proof of origin and still be treated as originating.

Approved exporter provision refers to exporters who fulfil certain conditions, export frequently under and FTA and are registered with the local customs authorities (have obtained an approved exporter authorisation).

A provision that lists national authorities responsible for overseeing origin-related provisions and for issuing the certificate of origin. This is often the government or a government department which can then delegate the procedure of issuing certificates to other domestic organisations.
A provision that specifies the length of time an origin certificate or an origin declaration (see proof of origin) is valid for from the moment it has been issued.
CooProvision.ProvisionLegalExtract:
Article 14 : VALIDITY OF CERTIFICATES OF ORIGIN
1 Certificates of origin shall remain valid for four (4) months, effective from the date of
issuance thereof by the country of export, and must be submitted during this period
of time to the competent authorities of the importing country.
2 It shall be permitted to accept certificates of origin submitted to the competent
authorities at the country of import after expiry of the certificate with a view to
enforcement of a preferential regime, in the event that the submission thereof shall
not be possible prior to the specified deadline, whether due to force majeure or
exceptional circumstances, as deemed appropriate by the country of import.
3 The competent customs authorities of the country of import may accept certificates
of origin submitted after the specified deadline, in case the submission of respective
products is made prior to the deadline.

CooProvision.ProvisionGlossary: A provision that specifies who (exporter, producer who issued a supplier declaration, importer, issuing or accepting customs authority) and for what period of time needs to retain the proof of origin.
CooProvision.ProvisionLegalExtract:
Article 16 : MAINTENANCE OF DOCUMENTS
1. Individual exporters requesting the issuance of a certificate of origin shall keep and
retain the original documents for at least three (3) years.
2. The competent authorities of the country of export upon issuance of a certificate of
origin shall hereby keep and retain the application request and the rest of
documents for at least three (3) years.
3. The competent authorities of the country of import shall hereby keep and retain the
certificate of origin and the bill submitted thereto for at least three (3) years.

CooProvision.ProvisionGlossary: A provision that allows to recover customs duties paid for originating goods at the time of import.
CooProvision.ProvisionLegalExtract:
Article 12 : PROCEDURES FOR ISSUANCE OF CERTIFICATES OF ORIGIN RETROACTIVELY
? On an exceptional basis, certificates of origin may be issued subsequent to the
export of products, in the event that such certificates are not issued in due course of
export, owing to errors or inadvertent omissions, or in case it has been ascertained
and established by the competent authorities that a certificate of origin has been
issued, but not been admitted on import based on technical grounds.
? Concerned exporters shall be required to indicate the place and date of export for
the products associated with the certificate of origin in the application form, as well
as the grounds for submission of the respective request.
? Endorsement of certificates of origin shall be made in Arabic and shall indicate the
following: ‘Issued Retroactively'.

CooProvision.ProvisionGlossary: A provision that lists documentation relating to imports of preferential goods that needs to be submitted at the point of import in addition to the proof of origin.

A provision that refers to a situation where the commercial invoice is issued by a party other than the party which manufactured the goods or a party from which premises the good has been shipped. This third party can be an entity related to the exporter or an unrelated party. The third party can be located in FTA territory or outside.

A provision which sets out a process for origin verification that an FTA party should follow if the customs authorities of that country have a reasonable doubt regarding the preferential origin of imported goods.
CooProvision.ProvisionLegalExtract:
Article 19 : VERIFICATION OF PROOF OF ORIGIN
1. Ex-post monitoring shall be undertaken with an aim to verify and validate the proofs
of origin, based on a sampling technique, when there are reasonable grounds for the
customs authorities of the importing countries to suspect or question the
authenticity of the related documents, or the status of origin of the materials
mentioned therein, or the extent to which the requirements defined in the present
Protocol are fulfilled.
2 In pursuance of the requirements of Paragraph No. (1) hereinabove, the competent
authorities of the country of import shall send back the concerned certificate of
origin and copies of related documents to the competent authorities of the country
of export, and shall share, when appropriate, the reasons of form and substance in
support of the request for enquiry.
3 In the event a decision is made by the competent authorities of the country of
import to suspend the preferential treatment extended to the concerned products
during the course of enquiry, the concerned importer may opt for release of the
respective merchandise, without prejudice to the preventive measures deemed
appropriate thereby, in pursuance of the laws and regulations in force in both countries.
4 The competent authorities requesting such enquiry shall be informed of the results
and findings thereof at the earliest possible opportunity, no later than 3 months with
provision for possible extension for similar periods, as needed. Such findings and
outcomes shall indicate the accuracy of concerned documents, whether the
concerned products have originated in Jordan or Egypt and whether they meet all
the requirements set forth in the present Protocol.
5 In the event of reasonable suspicion, and in the absence of a reply during the period
defined above, starting from the date of submission of request of enquiry, or if the
reply does not include sufficient information regarding the authenticity and accuracy
of the concerned document of origin or the actual origin of the concerned products,
the competent customs authorities shall hereby decline to grant preferential
treatment to such products, save in exceptional cases.

CooProvision.ProvisionGlossary: A provision that specifies the legal consequences of submitting an origin documentation based on incorrect or falsified information. These can relate to criminal, civil and administrative penalties.
CooProvision.ProvisionLegalExtract:
Article 22 : PENALTIES
The competent authorities of both countries shall hereby inflict the penalties established in
the laws currently in force therein on each and every person, who has produced or ordered
the production of a document that contains inaccurate input or information with an aim to
grant preferential treatment to certain products.

CooProvision.ProvisionGlossary: A provision that allows an exporter or an importer to obtain an official and legally binding opinion on the classification, origin or customs value of their products from the local customs authorities prior to exporting/importing of the goods.
A provision that clarifies that when the origin of the goods is not in question, preferential origin claims should not be rejected as a result of small administrative errors and discrepancies.
CooProvision.ProvisionLegalExtract:
Article 17 : DIFFERENCES AND FORMAL ERRORS
1. Minor differences or simple variations detected in the data stated in the certificate
of origin and documents submitted to the customs authorities, with an aim to
complete the import of merchandise shall not automatically invalidate the certificate
of origin, if conformity of the imported goods is established and substantiated.
2. The certificate of origin may not be declined on the basis of obvious formal errors,
such as typographical errors, in case such errors do not give rise to questions or do
not bring uncertainties regarding the validity or accuracy of data stated therein.

CooProvision.ProvisionGlossary: A provision which sets up an appeal process in respect of origin determination and advanced rulings.

CHAPTER THREE (III)
Article 9 : DIRECT TRANSPORT
The exemption scheme provided for under the Agreement shall hereby solely apply to such
products and materials transported between Jordan and Egypt, without a transit route
through the territory of a third country.
Nevertheless, materials originating in Jordan or Egypt, which constitute a part of the same
consignment, may maintain the origin thereof, even though such shall be moved or
transported through the territory of other countries, and may be granted possible
arrangements of transport or interim storage, provided that such materials shall remain
under the surveillance and control of the customs authority of the country of transit, and
shall not be subjected to any other operations, with the exception of landing or trans-
shipment or any other operation intended for the maintenance thereof.
The process of indirect transport or transit of such products shall be acknowledged and
declared to the customs authority of the country of import, on the basis of:
? The waybill and transport documents performed at the country of export; and,
? The certificate issued by the customs authorities at the country of transit, containing
an exact description of the respective merchandise, the date of landing and trans-
shipment thereof, and the circumstances experienced by such products during the
passage or transit thereof.
In the absence of the above documentation, any other document issued and authorised by
the customs authorities of the country of import shall hereby be sufficient.
CHAPTER FOUR (IV)

For the purpose of the present Protocol, the following terms shall hereby mean the
following:
(A) Manufacturing: all the processes of operation (operations) or of transformation,
including operations of assembly and installations, and/ or other processes of production.
(B) Material: any component, input material, element and/ or part included in the
manufacturing or the transformation of any product.
(C) Product: any product manufactured or acquired from a process of manufacturing,
including production inputs used for another manufacturing process.
(D) Merchandise: both materials and products.
(E) Value for Customs Purposes: the value determined in accordance with the Customs
Valuation Agreement of the World Trade Organisation (WTO), with respect to the
enforcement of Chapter (VII) of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade of Year 1994
(F) Value of Originating Materials: the value of such materials as specified in Point No.
(H) and which is applied upon the delivery of all necessary operations of
manufacturing or transformation.
(G) Ex-Factory Price: the price paid for a product to the factory where the last operation
of manufacture or transformation takes place, including the value of all the materials
used, excluding domestic taxes which can be recovered upon export of the acquired product.
(H) Value of Foreign Materials: the value for customs purposes upon importation of
non-originating materials incorporated in the process of manufacture, or the initial
verifiable price performed for such materials in the country of import, in the event
that the value of such input materials is unspecified or unidentifiable. This value shall
include the CIF.
(I) Chapters, Headings and Sub-Headings: the chapters, headings, and sub-headings
used for the purpose of tariff classification, which are included in the Harmonized
System (H.S.) Code for the classification and nomenclature of goods and
commodities, under the present Protocol.
(J) Classification: the classification of products or materials under a certain heading.
(K) Value-Added: the value-added is calculated by deducting the foreign inputs included
in the final product (CIF) from the ex-factory price of the commodity.
(L) Consignment: the products dispatched at one time from the consigner to the
consignee, accompanied by a single bill of lading or shipping document.
Article 1 : Definitions

Article 2 : CRITERION OF ORIGIN
For the purposes of the present Protocol:
1. The following shall hereby be deemed to be originating in Jordan:
A. Products entirely acquired in Jordan, pursuant to Article No. (IV) of the present Protocol; and,
B. Products acquired in Jordan, which contain materials that not entirely acquired
therein, provided that such materials have been subjected to sufficient
processes of industrial transformation or manufacture in Jordan, as per the
2. The following shall hereby be deemed to be originating in Egypt:
A. Products entirely acquired in Egypt, pursuant to Article No. (IV) of the present Protocol; and,
B. Products acquired in Egypt, and which contain materials that are not entirely
acquired therein, provided that such materials have been subjected to sufficient
processes of industrial transformation or manufacture in Egypt, as per the
requirements established in Article No. (V) of the present Protocol.

GENERAL PROVISIONS

CHAPTER THREE (III)
Article 9 : DIRECT TRANSPORT
The exemption scheme provided for under the Agreement shall hereby solely apply to such
products and materials transported between Jordan and Egypt, without a transit route
through the territory of a third country.
Nevertheless, materials originating in Jordan or Egypt, which constitute a part of the same
consignment, may maintain the origin thereof, even though such shall be moved or
transported through the territory of other countries, and may be granted possible
arrangements of transport or interim storage, provided that such materials shall remain
under the surveillance and control of the customs authority of the country of transit, and
shall not be subjected to any other operations, with the exception of landing or trans-
shipment or any other operation intended for the maintenance thereof.
The process of indirect transport or transit of such products shall be acknowledged and
declared to the customs authority of the country of import, on the basis of:
? The waybill and transport documents performed at the country of export; and,
? The certificate issued by the customs authorities at the country of transit, containing
an exact description of the respective merchandise, the date of landing and trans-
shipment thereof, and the circumstances experienced by such products during the
passage or transit thereof.
In the absence of the above documentation, any other document issued and authorised by
the customs authorities of the country of import shall hereby be sufficient.
CHAPTER FOUR (IV)

Article 5 : DETERMINATION OF ORIGIN
Pursuant to the provisions set out in Article No. (II) (Paragraph B) concerning determination
of the origin of merchandise manufactured in either Party, and which contain materials
originating from a third party, the criterion associated with share of domestic value-added
shall be considered to determine the rules of origin for such merchandise, provided that
such shall be no less than forty percent (40%).
The share of value-added shall be calculated as follows:
Share of Domestic Value-Added = [(Ex-Factory Value of Final Product - Value of Imported Materials Involved in the Manufacture)/Final Ex-Factory Value of Merchandise] x 100%
The criterion associated with the share of value added shall hereby constitute the basis for
such calculation, pursuant to provisions of the present Protocol, while taking into
consideration one of the two following criteria:
A. The change to customs-based classification, with clear identification of the headings
and sub-headings as a part of the Harmonised System (H.S. Code) up to six digits;
B. The manufacture processes, with clear identification of the specific process that
determines the origin of the concerned good/ commodity.

Article 12 : PROCEDURES FOR ISSUANCE OF CERTIFICATES OF ORIGIN RETROACTIVELY
PROCEDURES FOR ISSUANCE OF CERTIFICATES OF ORIGIN RETROACTIVELY
? On an exceptional basis, certificates of origin may be issued subsequent to the
export of products, in the event that such certificates are not issued in due course of
export, owing to errors or inadvertent omissions, or in case it has been ascertained
and established by the competent authorities that a certificate of origin has been
issued, but not been admitted on import based on technical grounds.
? Concerned exporters shall be required to indicate the place and date of export for
the products associated with the certificate of origin in the application form, as well
as the grounds for submission of the respective request.
? Endorsement of certificates of origin shall be made in Arabic and shall indicate the
following: ‘Issued Retroactively'.
Article 13 : PROCEDURES FOR ISSUANCE OF SUBSTITUTE CERTIFICATE OF ORIGIN
PROCEDURES FOR ISSUANCE OF SUBSTITUTE CERTIFICATE OF ORIGIN
1 In case of theft, loss or damage of a certificate of origin, the concerned exporter may
apply to the competent authorities that issued the initial certificate to request the
issuance of a substitute copy on the basis of the documents of export in the possession thereof.
2 Endorsement of a substitute certificate of origin shall be made in Arabic and shall
indicate the following, ‘Certified True Copy of Initial Certificate'. The substitute
certificate shall bear the same date of issuance of the initial certificate of origin. This
shall be taken into consideration when calculating the terms of validity and time
limits of the respective certificate of origin.
Article 14 : VALIDITY OF CERTIFICATES OF ORIGIN
VALIDITY OF CERTIFICATES OF ORIGIN
1 Certificates of origin shall remain valid for four (4) months, effective from the date of
issuance thereof by the country of export, and must be submitted during this period
of time to the competent authorities of the importing country.
2 It shall be permitted to accept certificates of origin submitted to the competent
authorities at the country of import after expiry of the certificate with a view to
enforcement of a preferential regime, in the event that the submission thereof shall
not be possible prior to the specified deadline, whether due to force majeure or
exceptional circumstances, as deemed appropriate by the country of import.
3 The competent customs authorities of the country of import may accept certificates
of origin submitted after the specified deadline, in case the submission of respective
products is made prior to the deadline.
Article 15 : SUBMISSION OF CERTIFICATES OF ORIGIN
SUBMISSION OF CERTIFICATES OF ORIGIN
Certificates of origin shall be submitted to the competent authorities of the country of
import in conformity with the procedures in place in each country and shall be drawn up in
Arabic, pursuant to the template applicable within the League of Arab States (LAS).
Article 16 : MAINTENANCE OF DOCUMENTS
MAINTENANCE OF DOCUMENTS
1. Individual exporters requesting the issuance of a certificate of origin shall keep and
retain the original documents for at least three (3) years.
2. The competent authorities of the country of export upon issuance of a certificate of
origin shall hereby keep and retain the application request and the rest of
documents for at least three (3) years.
3. The competent authorities of the country of import shall hereby keep and retain the
certificate of origin and the bill submitted thereto for at least three (3) years.

Article 17 : DIFFERENCES AND FORMAL ERRORS
1. Minor differences or simple variations detected in the data stated in the certificate
of origin and documents submitted to the customs authorities, with an aim to
complete the import of merchandise shall not automatically invalidate the certificate
of origin, if conformity of the imported goods is established and substantiated.
2. The certificate of origin may not be declined on the basis of obvious formal errors,
such as typographical errors, in case such errors do not give rise to questions or do
not bring uncertainties regarding the validity or accuracy of data stated therein.

Article 18 : FORMS AND STAMPS
1. The competent authorities responsible for certification of origin in either country
shall hereby provide each other with samples of all stamps intended for certification
of origin, as well as contact information of competent authorities responsible for
validation of such certificates and billing statements and invoice data.
2. To ensure the proper and sound execution of the present Protocol, both Egypt and
Jordan shall provide assistance in respect of validation of the accuracy and
authenticity of the certificates of origins and/ or the billing statements and invoice
data included therein through the competent departments.

Article 12 : PROCEDURES FOR ISSUANCE OF CERTIFICATES OF ORIGIN RETROACTIVELY
PROCEDURES FOR ISSUANCE OF CERTIFICATES OF ORIGIN RETROACTIVELY
? On an exceptional basis, certificates of origin may be issued subsequent to the

Article 13 : PROCEDURES FOR ISSUANCE OF SUBSTITUTE CERTIFICATE OF ORIGIN
PROCEDURES FOR ISSUANCE OF SUBSTITUTE CERTIFICATE OF ORIGIN
1 In case of theft, loss or damage of a certificate of origin, the concerned exporter may
apply to the competent authorities that issued the initial certificate to request the
issuance of a substitute copy on the basis of the documents of export in the possession thereof.
2 Endorsement of a substitute certificate of origin shall be made in Arabic and shall
indicate the following, ‘Certified True Copy of Initial Certificate'. The substitute
certificate shall bear the same date of issuance of the initial certificate of origin. This
shall be taken into consideration when calculating the terms of validity and time
limits of the respective certificate of origin.
Article 14 : VALIDITY OF CERTIFICATES OF ORIGIN
VALIDITY OF CERTIFICATES OF ORIGIN
1 Certificates of origin shall remain valid for four (4) months, effective from the date of
issuance thereof by the country of export, and must be submitted during this period
of time to the competent authorities of the importing country.
2 It shall be permitted to accept certificates of origin submitted to the competent
authorities at the country of import after expiry of the certificate with a view to
enforcement of a preferential regime, in the event that the submission thereof shall
not be possible prior to the specified deadline, whether due to force majeure or
exceptional circumstances, as deemed appropriate by the country of import.
3 The competent customs authorities of the country of import may accept certificates
of origin submitted after the specified deadline, in case the submission of respective
products is made prior to the deadline.
Article 15 : SUBMISSION OF CERTIFICATES OF ORIGIN
SUBMISSION OF CERTIFICATES OF ORIGIN
Certificates of origin shall be submitted to the competent authorities of the country of
import in conformity with the procedures in place in each country and shall be drawn up in
Arabic, pursuant to the template applicable within the League of Arab States (LAS).
Article 16 : MAINTENANCE OF DOCUMENTS
MAINTENANCE OF DOCUMENTS
1. Individual exporters requesting the issuance of a certificate of origin shall keep and
retain the original documents for at least three (3) years.
2. The competent authorities of the country of export upon issuance of a certificate of
origin shall hereby keep and retain the application request and the rest of
documents for at least three (3) years.
3. The competent authorities of the country of import shall hereby keep and retain the
certificate of origin and the bill submitted thereto for at least three (3) years.

Article 20 : FREE-TRADE ZONES
The Parties hereto shall take all necessary measures to ensure that the products traded
between the two countries and accompanied by a certificate of origin, and which pass
through a free-trade zone within the territory of either Party, are not replaced with other
products and are not subjected to operations other than the regular processes intended to
keep and maintain them in their natural condition. The concerned importer shall be under
the obligation to submit a proof in substantiation thereof.

Article 21 : CONSULTATION
With the intention of maximizing the benefits yielded by the Parties hereto, special
consideration shall be given to mutual consultation so as to ensure harmonization of the
rules of origin against the agreement concluded between the two Parties and any of the
regional and international economic blocs, without prejudice to the obligations assumed by
either Party towards such agreements.

PROCEDURES FOR ISSUANCE OF SUBSTITUTE CERTIFICATE OF ORIGIN
1 In case of theft, loss or damage of a certificate of origin, the concerned exporter may
apply to the competent authorities that issued the initial certificate to request the
issuance of a substitute copy on the basis of the documents of export in the possession thereof.
2 Endorsement of a substitute certificate of origin shall be made in Arabic and shall
indicate the following, ‘Certified True Copy of Initial Certificate'. The substitute
certificate shall bear the same date of issuance of the initial certificate of origin. This
shall be taken into consideration when calculating the terms of validity and time
limits of the respective certificate of origin.
Article 14 : VALIDITY OF CERTIFICATES OF ORIGIN
VALIDITY OF CERTIFICATES OF ORIGIN
1 Certificates of origin shall remain valid for four (4) months, effective from the date of
issuance thereof by the country of export, and must be submitted during this period
of time to the competent authorities of the importing country.
2 It shall be permitted to accept certificates of origin submitted to the competent
authorities at the country of import after expiry of the certificate with a view to
enforcement of a preferential regime, in the event that the submission thereof shall
not be possible prior to the specified deadline, whether due to force majeure or
exceptional circumstances, as deemed appropriate by the country of import.
3 The competent customs authorities of the country of import may accept certificates
of origin submitted after the specified deadline, in case the submission of respective
products is made prior to the deadline.
Article 15 : SUBMISSION OF CERTIFICATES OF ORIGIN
SUBMISSION OF CERTIFICATES OF ORIGIN
Certificates of origin shall be submitted to the competent authorities of the country of
import in conformity with the procedures in place in each country and shall be drawn up in
Arabic, pursuant to the template applicable within the League of Arab States (LAS).
Article 16 : MAINTENANCE OF DOCUMENTS
MAINTENANCE OF DOCUMENTS
1. Individual exporters requesting the issuance of a certificate of origin shall keep and
retain the original documents for at least three (3) years.
2. The competent authorities of the country of export upon issuance of a certificate of
origin shall hereby keep and retain the application request and the rest of
documents for at least three (3) years.
3. The competent authorities of the country of import shall hereby keep and retain the
certificate of origin and the bill submitted thereto for at least three (3) years.

Article 23 : CONFLICT RESOLUTION
In case a conflicts or a dispute arises regarding ex-post monitoring of the proofs of origin as
stipulated in the present Protocol, and which cannot be settled by the competent
authorities, such a conflict or a dispute shall hereby be referred to the Joint Trade
Committee in order to examine and recommend the measures necessary for the settlement
and elimination thereof, including prohibition of trade transactions with any exporter who is
found to be in breach of the rules of origin, without prejudice to applicable laws and
regulations in both countries, with a timely notification given to the other Party regarding
such measures. In all cases, settlement of disputes or conflicts arising between an importer
and the competent customs authorities in the country of import shall hereby remain subject
to the national legislation thereof.

Articles.ArticleTitle: COMMITTEE ON SUBSTANTIVE AND ADMINISTRATIVE COOPERATION
Articles.ArticleDesc:
Article 24 : COMMITTEE ON SUBSTANTIVE AND ADMINISTRATIVE COOPERATION
A committee on administrative and substantive cooperation shall hereby be formed of
relevant experts from both countries, and shall be responsible to:
1. Follow through the proper and uniform execution of the present Protocol; and,
2. Assume the necessary measures for inspection of factories and production facilities
to ensure the authenticity of the origin of merchandise at the request of either Party.

Articles.ArticleTitle: The respective Joint Trade Committee may hereby make decisions to amend any of the
Articles.ArticleDesc:
Article 25 : The respective Joint Trade Committee may hereby make decisions to amend any of the
provisions included in the present Protocol.

Articles.ArticleTitle: The present Protocol shall hereby form an integral part of the Reciprocal Free Trade
Articles.ArticleDesc:
Article 26 : The present Protocol shall hereby form an integral part of the Reciprocal Free Trade
Agreement signed between Egypt and Jordan on 10 December 1998.

Article 27 : SUPPLEMENTS
? The supplements to the present Protocol shall hereby constitute an integral part thereof.
? The Joint Committee may propose amendments regarding the certificate of origin
and the supplements thereof.

Article 28 : APPLICATION OF THE PROTOCOL
Egypt and Jordan shall hereby take all the measures necessary for the application of the
present Protocol.
The present Protocol is done and signed in Amman on 21 Sha'ban 1419 AH, corresponding

Article 12 : PROCEDURES FOR ISSUANCE OF CERTIFICATES OF ORIGIN RETROACTIVELY
PROCEDURES FOR ISSUANCE OF CERTIFICATES OF ORIGIN RETROACTIVELY
? On an exceptional basis, certificates of origin may be issued subsequent to the
export of products, in the event that such certificates are not issued in due course of
export, owing to errors or inadvertent omissions, or in case it has been ascertained
and established by the competent authorities that a certificate of origin has been
issued, but not been admitted on import based on technical grounds.
? Concerned exporters shall be required to indicate the place and date of export for
the products associated with the certificate of origin in the application form, as well
as the grounds for submission of the respective request.
? Endorsement of certificates of origin shall be made in Arabic and shall indicate the
following: ‘Issued Retroactively'.
Article 13 : PROCEDURES FOR ISSUANCE OF SUBSTITUTE CERTIFICATE OF ORIGIN
PROCEDURES FOR ISSUANCE OF SUBSTITUTE CERTIFICATE OF ORIGIN
1 In case of theft, loss or damage of a certificate of origin, the concerned exporter may
apply to the competent authorities that issued the initial certificate to request the
issuance of a substitute copy on the basis of the documents of export in the possession thereof.
2 Endorsement of a substitute certificate of origin shall be made in Arabic and shall
indicate the following, ‘Certified True Copy of Initial Certificate'. The substitute
certificate shall bear the same date of issuance of the initial certificate of origin. This
shall be taken into consideration when calculating the terms of validity and time
limits of the respective certificate of origin.
Article 14 : VALIDITY OF CERTIFICATES OF ORIGIN
VALIDITY OF CERTIFICATES OF ORIGIN
1 Certificates of origin shall remain valid for four (4) months, effective from the date of
issuance thereof by the country of export, and must be submitted during this period
of time to the competent authorities of the importing country.
2 It shall be permitted to accept certificates of origin submitted to the competent
authorities at the country of import after expiry of the certificate with a view to
enforcement of a preferential regime, in the event that the submission thereof shall
not be possible prior to the specified deadline, whether due to force majeure or
exceptional circumstances, as deemed appropriate by the country of import.
3 The competent customs authorities of the country of import may accept certificates
of origin submitted after the specified deadline, in case the submission of respective
products is made prior to the deadline.
Article 15 : SUBMISSION OF CERTIFICATES OF ORIGIN
SUBMISSION OF CERTIFICATES OF ORIGIN
Certificates of origin shall be submitted to the competent authorities of the country of
import in conformity with the procedures in place in each country and shall be drawn up in
Arabic, pursuant to the template applicable within the League of Arab States (LAS).
Article 16 : MAINTENANCE OF DOCUMENTS
MAINTENANCE OF DOCUMENTS
1. Individual exporters requesting the issuance of a certificate of origin shall keep and
retain the original documents for at least three (3) years.
2. The competent authorities of the country of export upon issuance of a certificate of
origin shall hereby keep and retain the application request and the rest of
documents for at least three (3) years.
3. The competent authorities of the country of import shall hereby keep and retain the
certificate of origin and the bill submitted thereto for at least three (3) years.
